subject: Green Sunday
event:
It was a good day to be wearing green in the NFL.

The Jets won their morning game convincingly, even with Mark Sanchez nursing his knees back in New York City and Kellen Clemens playing abysmally in his stead.  Hardly mattered.  Gang Green's running game was hitting, and the defense played lights out.  Of course, they were in Tampa Bay playing this year's Bucs, so it hardly counted.  Josh Freeman, the heralded Bucs rookie QB, looked just awful, but maybe some of that was Rex Ryan's D.  Still, these Bucs are so bad they ought to make them go back and wear the creamsicle uniforms until they start playing better.  

The Jets are still in the playoff hunt, but just barely.  They pretty much have to win out, and with the Colts and the Bengals on their schedule, I think that's unlikely.  And next week they have to beat Atlanta, who have a bad record but gave the Saints all they could handle today.  

Green Bay won as well.  Another "green" team.

And, sadly, this evening the midnight green Iggles of Philadelphia defeated my Giants in a heartbreaker.  All the talking heads are saying what a great game it was.  Pfui.  It was an EXCITING game, yes.  The G-Men came out stumbling and spotted the Iggles to a two touchdown lead, then battled back for the rest of the game.  Every time they closed the gap to one score the Eagles would get punch in another one and widen it again.  Finally the Giants managed to take a one-point lead at 31-30... only to have the Eagles get a long TD on the very first play after the kickoff.  The scoring continued after that, and finally ended 45-38 in favor of Philadelphia.  The Giants racked up a ridiculous number of passing yards, and both teams left points on the board.  McNabb missed one wide-open receiver who was streaking downfield for what should have been a certain touchdown, receiver Mario Manningham of the G-Men had two endzone receptions disallowed for having one foot out of bounds, and his fellow wideout Hakeem Nicks had a couple of TD passes bounce off his hands.  There was also a Giants linebacker who dropped what would have been a certain pick-six served up by McNabb.  It too bounced off his hands.  (And weirdly, it wasn't a pass after all, but a forward fumble, but after our LB dropped it players on both teams just ignored the live ball lying there on the grass).  There were fumbles, a punt return for a TD, an freaky pass broken up by an Eagle that caromed off his thigh into the hands of the Giants tight end... lots of crazy, colorful, thrilling stuff.  Both teams played hard.

But a great game?  Pfui.  For fans like me, who appreciate defense, it was far from that.  Neither team brought their defense, from what I saw.  The Giants certainly proved themselves unable to stop the Eagles.  After ranking as the best defense in the NFL at season's start, our D has fallen apart.  Especially the pass rush.  McNabb had all day back there.  Eli played one of the best games I have ever seen him play -- his stats were off the charts, and would have been obscene if Manningham could have stayed in bounds and Nicks could have caught the balls that were bouncing off him -- despite the fact that he was under pressure every snap.  McNabb, on the other hand, could have filled out and filed his tax return in the pocket on a couple of those plays.  What the hell happened to the Giants' fearsome pass rush?  We have the same players as last year and the year before.  With added depth; by rights we should be better.  But Bill Sheridan, our new defensive coordinator, does not have them playing the same agressive attacking style that Spags did last year, that has made a world of difference.  Sheridan needs to go.  I want my Big Blue D back.  I like winning games 13-10 much more than losing them 45-38.  

Oddly, despite the loss, the Giants may still have a better chance of making the playoffs than the Jets do, provided the Cowboys continue their traditional December collapse.  But I am not holding my breath.  Next week's game against the Redskins has the look of a classic trap game.  After getting up emotionally for the big games against Dallas and Phillie, the Giants are all too likely to suffer a bad letdown against the Skins and get upset, which would effectively end their season.  I've seen it happen before.  And Washinton is better than its record.  And even if they get past the Skins, the Vikings are waiting at season's end.  The only silver lining in the clouds over the Meadowlands is the fact that the Giants own the tiebreakers over the Cowboys, so if both teams finish with the same record, New York goes to the playoffs and Dallas stays home.  But right now Dallas is a game up.

Life is magical... but full of pain.

comments.article: When I first glimpsed the size of this new blog entry, I got really excited. And then I realized it's about American football.
comments.subject: Excitement

comments.article: Yeah,the Eagles/Giants game was a bit disappointing.And I can't see them getting past my Vikings who are having a stellar season.

I've a new, special toast for Giants-Eagles games. It's entitled, "A Dance With Flagons."

Ale is involved. Also footwork. Possibly tomfoolery.

And Washinton is better than its record.

Oh no they aren't. Like Bill Parcells said: you are who your record says you are.

The only threat from the Redskins now is that everybody is either playing for their jobs, or auditioning for whatever team they'll end up at. Zorn is done. Vinnie Cerrato is probably done. Jason Campbell is done. Clinton Portis is done. ...team is basically done.

They did look good against the Raiders, though.
after the cowboys leave the dome next week, their record won't have improved any.
comments.subject: good news!

comments.article:
Actually got to see the Giants game - the disallowed Manningham TD was really a shame, as was the almost-INT. As for Eli, I was shocked that he didn't protect the ball better on his scramble late in the game - it's not like he was going to throw it.

The only silver lining in the clouds over the Meadowlands is the fact that the Giants own the tiebreakers over the Cowboys

Speaking of owning tiebreakers... *ahem* :->
Hah. A good day for the Dolphins, wasn't it? If they can just keep this up, a playoff berth seems like good odds. *crosses fingers*

It looks unlikely that they'll be in striking distance of New Orleans for home field all the way, but they're fairly likely to already have the first round bye locked up, so they might not have anything to play for in their final game.  Which would mean I wouldn't even have to be hoping the Giants lose.  Go Vikings!
comments.subject: Might not have to worry so much about the Vikes

comments.article:
Yeah, the last game of the season will likely be meaningless for the Vikings and the rest of the games for the Colts and well. I think both teams remaining schedules are easier than they appear.

Though the Vikings may still prove dangerous as T-Jack plays lights out in low pressure games.
comments.subject: Re: Might not have to worry so much about the Vikes

comments.article:
Still, these Bucs are so bad they ought to make them go back and wear the creamsicle uniforms until they start playing better.

Considering that they were wearing the creamsicles during the only game they've won this year, that plan just might work.

Yeah, but they may pick up win #2 over my Seahawks this week. They played quite possibly the worst game I've seen them play EVER against the Texans, making Matt Schaub look like Johnny Unitas. Forsett, who was supposed to be "featured," spent most of his time on the sidelines. Hasselbeck stumbled, fumbled and bumbled the entire game; apparently auditioning for the Raiders QB job next year. That was just a joke of an effort, but the only game Seattle won against a team with a prayer of going to the post season was their surprising shut out of J'ville. The remaining schedule is brutal after the Bucs, so the question is will we finish 5-11 or 6-10? Either is a slight improvement on last seasons 4-12 mark, but I think that team played better, with heart and intensity despite being decimated with injuries.

The difference between the two teams, at least in my opinion, was that the Giants choked on their big offensive plays and the Eagles didn't. Without dropping *easy* (for the NFL) passes, missing clear turnover opportunities, and some questionable footwork in the endzone, the Giants would have won this game comfortably. They beat themselves more than anything. My sympathy is with Eli this morning, who other than that bizarre fumble had a terrific game and was let down by his receiving corps and defense.

My bet is that the Jets beat the Bengals. The Bengals offense has gone missing in the last several games; they've committed a ton of penalties in the last three games; when they play the Jets, chances are that by then, they will have clinched their division (in which case they'll be relaxing), and the Jets will be playing for a chance to extend the season, at home.

That says "Jets Win" to me... especially no one's ever gone wrong betting against the Bungles.
I'm going with the Bengals in this one.  They'll come out with a lot of emotional intensity due to the death of Chris Henry.

"Still, these Bucs are so bad they ought to make them go back and wear the creamsicle uniforms until they start playing better."

Oddly enough, we wore those uniforms against Green Bay, the only game we've won all year long.
I never thought I would see the day when the Giants' defense was the problem rather than its offense.

I tend to agree with the Washington statement. I am biased for being a Redskins fan but they did almost beat the Saints; they took them to overtime. Of course, they also lost to the Lions and Kansas City (and a bunch of other less than stellar teams). I do have faith in them though. With that being said, out of the NFC East I would love to see the Giants go to the playoffs over the much hated Cowboys and the Eagles.

I do have faith in them though.

As a 26 yr old life-long Northern Virginia native and Redskins fan, I giggle at this statement, because really, haven't we all held hope that a zombie JKC would come back to bitch slap everybody, eat Snyder's brain, and restore our team to its former glory?

My Sunday night was magical if tainted by the growing suspicion that the Eagles will never get far in the playoffs with a secondary this lousy at tackling.

Sports enjoyment is for those that win and those who have no stake in either side like those talking heads. At halftime I was marveling at what a fun, "great" game it was as well. But my team had been leading the whole time. And continued to lead for 99% of the game overall. If I had been in your Giant-rooting shoes I probably would be miserable for most of it.
comments.subject: Enjoyment is relative

comments.article: Yeah yeah you guys have fun talking about your winning teams while i have to watch the Chiefs find new and interesting ways to lose each week. bleh
comments.subject: Talk it up....

comments.article:
Bink! Boink! Sunk! The Giants aren't making it to the playoffs. McKenzie's re-injury sees to that. We have seen Dallas perform well against good teams this season. We have yet to see the Giants do the same. They are done.

Hopefully, Tom and Jerry will let Sherridan go and not give him a pass because of all of the injuries to keystone players. He may be "brilliant" like Sean Payton was when he penned his "War and Peace"/"Thunder and Lightening" of offensive schemes, just not here.

While they are at it. If they bring back Pierce I hope it's as LB coach. His days as a starter are done, but he's football and media savvy. I think he will be a head coach someday. They also need to upgrade the defense... all of it. I hope they decide, finally, on what they want Kiwi to be. First they had him as a pass rusher, then they made him a LB, now they have him as a sometimes drop back lineman who plays the run and rushes the passer. Poor kid.

They also need a running back like Bradshaw, only... football smarter. Can somebody please explain to me why Jacobs isn't the feature back? Whatever happened to handing the ball to big hog 20-24 times? Seems like they are still stuck with the Thunder and Lightening hangover. Where are you Derrick Ward?

Jets have over-achieved. Or, maybe Rex is the reason. Or, the "D." "D" as in Darelle. After a season and a 3/4ths, Thomas Jones seems to have finally found his old legs. Good for him. If Sanchez can mature as a man and stop behaving like he's a 15 year old who's parents went out of town for the weekend... I wonder if they can send him to military school? At least now the Sanchez vs. Clemens debate should be over.

Strangely, I am not sad that both the Jets and Giants seasons are over. This has not been a winter of discontent. There's quality in them and they are easy to root for. And, if they make it to the, I'll gladly eat crow.
comments.subject: Foibles and Fumbles.

comments.article: I'm a huge Cowboys fan, and as much as I would very much like my team to be in the playoffs, I have serious doubts.  Original prediction for the seasons was between 8-8 and 10-6.  Despite Tony Romo playing the best ball of his career, the defense is going to let the offense down, and if the Cowboys are lucky, they'll beat the Redskins and possibly the Eagles.  Your Giants may have a chance depending on which Eli comes to play ball (the one who streaked to go to the Super Bowl or the other one).
I really hope that Ware is alright and that the neck sprain isn't too serious.
I got to agree with you , I miss the days of 13-10 Eagles Giants games.
comments.subject: Game

comments.article: More football stuff? Jeez. Torture.
comments.subject: Whoah

comments.article: Well, the Steelers are in even worse shape than the Jets or Giants. So you have that going for you.

No kidding, did they finally run out of $500 bills for the refs or something?  No more phantom holding calls, and they're throwing flags at poor Hines Ward for Offensive Interference and Crack-back blocking!  Being a Seattle fan, there is a certain feeling of sick satisfaction--even exhultation--at watching the Steelers implode.  The Cleveland game was especially entertaining.  It makes up a bit for the fact that the Seahawks are awful this season.
I need the Bucs to don those creamsicle uniforms one more time, if for no other reason than to allow my woebegotten Rams to get the number one draft pick.
The Rams need more than a #1 draft pick. They need a complete makeover. I've also heard they may move back to L.A.

Life can indeed be full of pain if you're a football fan.  My dad has been a Vikings fan since 1961 and had to watch his team lose the Super Bowl 4 times and still hasn't seen them win one.  So if my Vikings beat your team, I'm not gonna feel bad about it!

George, your pain is relative.  As a Redskins fan, I have been subjected to the torturous tenure of none other than one Snyderatto.   You have two teams fighting their hearts out for potential playoff spots in mid-december while the skins...(sigh).  i have been forced to adopt the vikings as my home away from home team for now.  ergo: I look forward to the Gmen's next two meetings, as i believe i will have your number on both accounts.  If nothing else, my unfortunately named rskinz can be an effective spoiler, while my newly adopted brethren can rub your face it it.  consider gauntlets thrown!
comments.subject: Fubbal

comments.article: No mention of the Aquamarine Green of the victorious Dolphins, who have swept your Jets this year?
comments.subject: uh, you forgot another green team...

comments.article: Don't worry about the 'Skins, if there is one thing I have learned about being a fan, especially this season, is that no one can snatch defeat from the grips of victory like Washington can.  Buck up, I'm sure the Giants will have no troubles coming back to win in the 4th quarter...  =)
